awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Comparative analysis of malaria impacts on human and primate evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

Both humans and non-human primates have evolved defensive adaptations against malaria via changes in the genome. This doctoral dissertation research uses comparative primate data to advance knowledge about the co-evolution of primates and malaria or similar parasites, including how malaria has impacted the evolution of the primate immune system and identification of genetic mechanisms underlying the immune response to blood stage malaria. The project outcomes may inform public health relevant research on the human response to malaria. The project also supports outreach efforts that focus on increasing participation of underrepresented groups in STEM research through K-12 outreach and computational genomic capacity building. 

Using a comparative functional and evolutionary genomics approach, the researchers identify primate genes and pathways that are differentially expressed in response to malaria infection, including those with species-specific involvement in malaria response. The researchers also identify signatures of malaria-imposed changes across primate genomes. The study outcomes can advance understanding of how the primate immune system has evolved in response to this host-pathogen arms race. The analysis uses an innovative approach to investigate primate malaria response in natural transmission systems. This study can help to determine which malaria responses arose through the host-pathogen coevolutionary arms race as well as explore how human and primate evolution has been impacted by the selection pressure of malaria.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the relationship between the parasites that cause malaria (plus their relatives) and primates, examining this host-pathogen dynamic in both captive and wild settings, encompassing experimental and natural infections. The study significantly advanced our understanding of primates' response to malaria, spotlighting the molecular mechanisms driving their immune response to the blood stage of the disease. Importantly, it also established and confirmed a molecular method for gauging malaria infection intensity in primates, an advancement over the traditional, laborious microscopy techniques which are hard to implement when studying wild primates in field settings.

The study used data from various sources, including naturally infected red colobus monkeys and experimentally infected rhesus macaques, squirrel monkeys, and owl monkeys. A key aspect of the research involved examining how different primate species respond to malaria and related parasites at a molecular level. In rhesus macaques, differences in immune responses to two malaria parasites, Plasmodium coatneyi and P. cynomolgi, were uncovered. This finding is particularly relevant since these species are often used in laboratory studies to model human malaria. The study identified specific genes responsive to malaria infection and validated a new method for estimating parasite load by comparing it with traditional microscopy, confirming its efficacy in non-human primates. Intriguingly, genes showing variation between the two Plasmodium infections were linked to brain functions, hinting at the diverse effects these parasites have on the central nervous system. The research also investigated the Ugandan red colobus monkey response to Hepatocystis parasites. Despite the differences between Hepatocystis and Plasmodium (the latter including those that cause human disease), the monkeys' molecular response was found to mirror that of humans infected with malaria parasites. This aspect of the study was groundbreaking, as it was the first to investigate the transcriptomic response to an Apicomplexan parasite in a naturally infected, wild population, using the previously validated method for measuring parasite infection intensity. Another discovery came from the comparative study of squirrel and owl monkeys. Using single-cell RNA sequencing, the researchers explored how these primates responded to the human malaria parasite, Plasmodium vivax. The study compared the red blood cell transcriptomic correlates to malaria infection in these primates. These findings are significant for understanding human genetic adaptations to vivax malaria, particularly in relation to how the parasite invades red blood cells. Notably, the research found that red blood cell heterogeneity affects genes linked to malaria parasite load and identified differences in gene expression associated with the ACKR1 pathway, which aligns with known differences in Plasmodium vivax invasion pathways in these monkey species and some human populations.

In addition to the scientific insights, the project was a valuable development opportunity for the co-PI, particularly in acquiring essential bioinformatic skills for RNA sequencing and single-cell RNA sequencing data analysis. The results of this comprehensive research were shared with relevant scientific communities through manuscripts, conference presentations, and STEM outreach activities. The co-PI presented the findings at two conferences, published manuscripts (made openly available as preprints), submitted her dissertation, published all analysis software under open licenses, and participated in outreach programs over four semesters.
